fields.headline: £53m to revive languages in schools
fields.bodyText: Ministers unveiled a £53m package billed as reviving languages in schools yesterday - although it emerged that the figure is only £5m more than last year, and means an average of £340 extra for each school. Teenagers will be offered intensive language classes and university students will be sent into schools as "ambassadors" for languages. The £53m - pledged for the financial year starting in April - follows consistent concerns about the fall-off of language GCSEs since the government dropped it as a compulsory subject. In their children's plan last week ministers reaffirmed a promise to introduce compulsory languages by 2010 for all primary pupils. But opposition MPs pointed out that the funding only amounts to £5m more than last year. Split between the 14,700 schools, that gives £340 each on average to work towards compulsory primary language classes by 2010. The schools minister, Jim Knight, said: "Compulsory French or German GCSE study simply does not motivate pupils. We will generate enthusiasm and confidence for studying languages in secondary school and beyond - far more effective than simple compulsion." The number of candidates who took GCSEs in French dropped by almost 20,000 this year, or 8%, while German had the biggest percentage decrease of all GCSE subjects, down more than 10% on last year. Over half of England's secondary schools now teach languages to fewer than 50% of their GCSE pupils, according to research last month from Cilt, the national centre for languages. In one in 10 schools more than 90% of pupils were not studying languages, the research found. " David Laws, the Liberal Democrat education spokesman, said: "The government has made a total pig's ear of modern languages in our schools. Ministers should have put in place their modern language strategy for primary schools before making language GCSEs optional." A spokesman for the Department for Children, Schools and Families said that 70% of primary schools were already teaching languages.
